questions.text: A 9-month-old girl with a history of recurrent pulmonary infections is found to have a congenital deficiency of adenosine deaminase, which is associated with a virtual absence of lymphocytes in her peripheral lymphoid organs. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe combined immunodeficiency

Option D:

  • Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is a group of disorders of T and B lymphocytes that are characterized by recurrent viral, bacterial, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Many infants with SCID have severely reduced volumes of lymphoid tissue and an immature thymus that lacks lymphocytes. In some patients, lymphocytes fail to develop beyond pre-B cells and pre-T cells.
  • Some children with SCID have adenosine deaminase deficiency which causes the accumulation of intermediate products that are toxic to lymphocytes.

Explanation:

Option A: Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia: This is a disorder characterized by the absence of B cells and low levels of all immunoglobulins, but it does not typically involve T cells or adenosine deaminase deficiency.

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome: This condition is due to thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, leading to T cell deficiency. While it may present with recurrent infections, it is not associated with adenosine deaminase deficiency.

Option C: Isolated IgA deficiency: This is the most common primary immunodeficiency and usually presents with recurrent mucosal infections. It is characterized by low or absent IgA levels but does not involve a global lack of lymphocytes or adenosine deaminase deficiency.

Educational Objective:

SCID is a group of disorders involving both B and T cell deficiencies. Adenosine deaminase deficiency is a specific form of SCID that leads to the accumulation of metabolites toxic to lymphocytes, resulting in their absence.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely to be a pre-leukaemic condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paroxysmal cold haemoglobinuria

Option C:

PCH (paroxysmal cold hemoglobinu­ria) is an autoimmune haemolytic anemia due to IgG autoanti­bodies which bind to P blood group antigen and cause intravascu­lar hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and have recovery within a month.

Explanation:

Option A: “PNH: about 5% to 10% of patients eventually develop acute myeloid leukemia or a my­elodysplastic syndrome, possibly because hematopoietic stem cells have suffered some type of genetic damage’.

Option B:  Aplastic anemia results from a fundamental stem cell defect supported by the presence of karyotypic aberrations in many cases; the occasional trans­formation of aplasia into myeloid neoplasms, typically myelodysplasia or acute myeloid leukemia; and the asso­ciation with abnormally short telomeres.

Option D: The term “myelodysplastic syndrome” (MDS) refers to a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects that are associated with ineffective hematopoiesis and a high risk of transformation to AML.

Educational objective:

Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) is primarily an autoimmune hemolytic anemia and not commonly associated with transformation to leukemia, which makes it the least likely condition to be pre-leukemic.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 545)

questions.text: In a clinical scenario where a male child presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia, which of the following genetic evaluations is most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) WASP gene mutation

 

Option B:

WASP gene mutation: WASP gene mutations are associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and immunodeficiency, which can include a high risk of infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection: The detection of B cell tyrosine kinase activity is relevant for X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which is characterized by the absence of mature B cells and low levels of immunoglobulins. This condition does not typically present with eczema or thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C: Adenosine deaminase activity: Reduced or absent adenosine deaminase activity is characteristic of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), which presents with severe recurrent infections. However, SCID does not typically involve eczema or thrombocytopenia as presenting features.

 

Option D: ANA titre: ANA titres are typically measured when autoimmune conditions, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), are suspected. These conditions can present with rash and are associated with immune dysregulation, but they do not typically cause thrombocytopenia as a primary manifestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a male child with recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia, the most appropriate genetic evaluation is testing for WASP gene mutations to confirm a diagnosis of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

questions.text: A 1 year old boy had complaints of recurrent fever. He had been treated for severe pneumonia 3 weeks back. Clinical examination revealed mild pallor, oral thrush, micrognathia, low-set right ear. Skin examination was remarkable with patchy hypopigmentation around face, trunk, back, abdomen, perianal region, hands and feet along with hypopigmented silver gray hair. Peripheral smear showed abnormal inclusions as shown in the given image. Identify the defect associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective phagolysosome fusion

 

Option B:

 

The diagnosis Chediak-Higashi syndrome- defect in phagolysosome fusion

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Seen in Chronic granulomatous disease.

 

Option C. MPO deficiency - This condition has minimal susceptibility to infection.

 

Option D. Associated with X-linked SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency disease)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is diagnosed by the presence of giant granules in leukocytes and is caused by a defect in the fusion of phagosomes with lysosomes, leading to impaired microbial killing.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed- Pg: 82,83

questions.text: A child presents with cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, and recurrent respiratory infections. Laboratory investigations show immunodeficiency. Which immunoglobulin is most commonly deficient in this patient, who is likely to have Ataxia-Telangiectasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgA

Explanation:

  • Patients with ataxia telangiectasia (AT) present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions associated with deficits in cerebellar function and nystagmus. There is a high incidence of recurrent pulmonary infections (bronchiectasis) and neoplasms of the lymphatic and reticuloendothelial system.
  • It is caused due to defect in DNA repair genes.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with cellular and humoral (IgA and IgG2) immunodeficiencies, premature aging and endocrine disorders such as insulin resistance or type-I DM.
  • The most striking neuropathologic changes include loss of Purkinje, granule and basket cells in the cerebellar cortex as well as of neurons in the deep cerebellar nuclei.
  • A poorly developed or absent thymus gland is the most consistent defect of the lymphoid system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most consistent immunoglobulin deficiency observed in Ataxia-Telangiectasia is IgA.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 242-243)

questions.text: Which of the following lesions/conditions shows most specific anatomic changes in HIV infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CNS lesions

 

Option C:

CNS Lesions: Central nervous system (CNS) lesions in HIV-infected patients can show specific pathologic changes, such as those seen in HIV encephalitis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, or primary CNS lymphoma, which are more diagnostic of HIV's effects on the brain compared to other conditions.

Explanation:

Option A: Lymph Nodes: Lymph nodes in HIV infection often show non-specific changes such as lymphadenopathy, which are not unique to HIV.

Option B: Opportunistic Infections: Opportunistic infections associated with HIV can present with a variety of histological patterns, depending on the organism involved, but these changes are not specific to HIV itself.

Option D: Kaposi’s Sarcoma (Blood Vessels): Kaposi’s sarcoma is associated with HIV infection but is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) infection. Its presence in the skin or organs isn't specific for HIV, as it can occur in other immunosuppressed states.

Educational Objective:

The CNS lesions in patients with HIV are among the few pathological findings that can be specific and diagnostic, reflecting the unique neuropathology associated with HIV infection and its complications.

Direct quote from Robbins…. “The anatomic changes in the tissues (except of lesions in the brain) are neither specific nor diagnostic”.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 254-255)

questions.text: In an HIV-positive patient presenting with neurological symptoms, imaging studies reveal a mass lesion in the brain. Which type of CNS neoplasm is most commonly associated with this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary CNS Iymphoma

 

Option C:

Primary CNS Lymphoma: Primary CNS lymphoma is frequently associated with immunosuppression seen in HIV-infected individuals, particularly when the CD4 count is low, and often has a correlation with EBV infection.

Explanation:

Option A: Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastoma is a type of malignant primary brain tumor most commonly found in children and is not particularly associated with HIV or immunosuppression.

Option B: Astrocytoma: Astrocytomas are a broad group of glial tumors and can occur in individuals with or without HIV. They are not the most common CNS neoplasm in the setting of HIV.

Option D: Ependymoma: Ependymomas are tumors derived from ependymal cells of the ventricular system and are not specifically associated with HIV or immunosuppression.

Educational Objective:

Primary CNS lymphoma is the most common CNS neoplasm in patients with HIV, particularly in those with severe immunosuppression. It is typically of B-cell origin and often associated with EBV infection.

 

(Ref: Robbins 9/e p254-255)

questions.text: A patient concerned about the risk of HIV transmission through medical products is reassured that certain blood products and derivatives are safe and do not pose a risk of transmitting HIV due to the methods of processing involved. Which of the following is NOT associated with the transmission of HIV?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasma derived Hepatitis B vaccine

Option C:

As per Harrison, Transfusions of whole blood, packed red blood cells, platelets, leukocytes, and plasma are all capable of transmitting HIV infection.

 In contrast, hyperimmune gamma globulin, hepatitis B immune globulin, plasma-derived hepatitis B vaccine, and Rho immune globulin have not been associated with transmission of HIV infection. The procedures involved in processing these products either inactivate or remove the virus. 

Plasma Derived Hepatitis B Vaccine: Plasma-derived Hepatitis B vaccines are processed to remove any viral particles, including HIV, effectively preventing the transmission of HIV.

Explanation:

Option A: Whole Blood: Transfusions of whole blood have a risk of HIV transmission if the blood is contaminated, as HIV can be present in sufficient quantities to establish an infection in the recipient.

Option B: Platelets: Platelet transfusions carry a risk of HIV transmission if the donor blood is infected, as platelets are derived from whole blood which may contain the virus.

Option D: Leukocytes: Transfusions involving leukocytes (white blood cells) can transmit HIV, as these cells can harbor the virus.

Educational Objective:

Plasma-derived Hepatitis B vaccines are not associated with the transmission of HIV because of the rigorous methods used to inactivate or remove viral contaminants during the manufacturing process

questions.text: In evaluating a 2-month-old infant for HIV infection, which diagnostic method is NOT appropriate due to the potential for false-positive results from passive transfer of maternal antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV ELISA 

Option C:

HIV ELISA is required for detection of antibodies against the virus. The antibodies may be present in the infant because of maternal infection also because IgG antibodies can cross the placental barrier. So, the presence of anti-HIV antibodies is not reliable for diagnosis of HIV in a 2-month-old child.

HIV ELISA: HIV ELISA detects HIV antibodies, which may be transferred from the mother to the infant, persisting for several months after birth. Therefore, it is not a reliable test for diagnosing HIV in an infant two months of age due to the potential for maternal antibody interference.

Explanation:

Option A: DNA-PCR: DNA-PCR is a sensitive method for detecting the presence of HIV DNA within a child's cells and can be used from birth to accurately diagnose congenital HIV infection.

Option B: Viral Culture: Viral culture using peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) can be used to grow the virus from the infant's blood cells, providing direct evidence of HIV infection.

Option D: P24 Antigen Assay: The p24 antigen assay detects viral core protein p24, which can be used to diagnose HIV infection in infants, as it is not affected by the presence of maternal antibodies.

Educational Objective:

In infants, direct detection methods for HIV such as DNA-PCR and p24 antigen assay are preferred over antibody detection methods like HIV ELISA, which can yield false-positive results due to the presence of maternal antibodies.

questions.text: A young truck driver with AIDS complains of difficulty swallowing. Examination of his oral cavity demonstrates whitish membranes covering much of his tongue and palate. He has similar lesions in his esophagus also. These pathologic findings are fundamentally caused by loss of which of the following immune cells in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Helper T lymphocytes.

Option B:

In HIV infection, infection of CD4+ (helper) T lymphocytes, which leads to the depletion of this cell population and impaired immune function. As a result, patients with AIDS usually die of opportunistic infections.

Helper T lymphocytes: HIV preferentially infects CD4+ helper T lymphocytes, leading to their depletion. The loss of helper T cells impairs cellular and humoral immunity, predisposing to opportunistic infections, such as oral candidiasis, indicated by the whitish membranes in the oral cavity and esophagus.

Explanation:

Option A: B lymphocytes: B lymphocytes are responsible for humoral immunity and produce antibodies. While B cell function can be affected secondary to T cell impairment in HIV, the primary defect in AIDS is not the direct loss of B cells.

Option C: Killer T lymphocytes: CD8+ killer T lymphocytes, or cytotoxic T cells, are essential for killing virus-infected cells. While these cells can be affected in HIV/AIDS, the primary immunologic defect causing the susceptibility to opportunistic infections in AIDS is the loss of helper T cells, not cytotoxic T cells.

Option D: Monocytes/macrophages: Monocytes/macrophages are involved in phagocytosis and antigen presentation. They can be infected by HIV and play a role in the disease pathogenesis, but the fundamental defect causing the increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections in AIDS is the loss of CD4+ helper T cells.

Educational Objective:

The depletion of CD4+ helper T lymphocytes is the hallmark of HIV infection leading to AIDS. The consequent immunosuppression manifests as susceptibility to opportunistic infections, including oral and esophageal candidiasis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent skin abscesses and infections. His medical history is significant for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). What is the underlying pathophysiology of CGD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Defects in phagocytic cell killing

 

Explanation:

 

CGD is an inherited disorder of the immune system that affects the function of phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. The underlying defect in CGD is a deficiency in one of the components of the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase complex, which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are necessary for the killing of ingested microorganisms. As a result, individuals with CGD are more susceptible to bacterial and fungal infections, as well as chronic granulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A neuropathologist is examining the brain from a patient with HIV, and, in the cerebral parenchyma, he identifies multinucleated cells. The virus is inducing a change in what type of cell to produce these giant cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microglial cells

 

Option D:

 

The presence of multinucleated giant cells in the cerebral parenchyma of a patient with HIV is indicative of HIV encephalitis. In HIV infection, the virus primarily infects and replicates in CD4+ T cells and macrophages/microglial cells. The multinucleated giant cells, also known as "syncytia," are formed by the fusion of infected microglial cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Neurons are not typically the target cells for HIV replication.

 

Option B: Astrocytes are not the primary target cells for HIV replication; microglial cells play a more significant role.

 

Option C: Oligodendroglial cells are not the primary target cells for HIV; microglial cells are more commonly infected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV encephalitis, specifically microglial cells contribute in the formation of multinucleated giant cells within the cerebral parenchyma.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1267
